Titre: The World's Most Well-Known Watchmakers Have a New Rival, a Jeweler Claiming Exclusive Rights in "Red Gold" - The Fashion Law
Contenu:
Luxury watchmakers have long wrestled with one very prominent set of opponents ‚Äì counterfeiters, the often-Chinese entities that actively saturate the market with ‚ÄúRolex‚Äù watches with hands that tick instead of glide, lighter-than-usual ‚ÄúAudemars Piguets,‚Äù and improperly engraved ‚ÄúPatek Philippes.‚Äù Over the past decade or so, an assertive new foe has arisen: a jeweler to the stars claiming exclusive rights in the words ‚Äúred gold,‚Äù and waging an increasingly aggressive war against nearly every major watchmaker ‚Äì from Cartier and Piaget to Breitling and Rolex ‚Äì in the process.

When jeweler Chris Aire opened the doors of his eponymous jewelry company 23 years ago in Beverly Hills, rose gold was far less popular than it is today. ‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt give rose gold away before we started branding it,‚Äù he told Bloomberg years later. The branding that Aire is referring to included calling the pink-hued gold-copper alloy ‚ÄúRed Gold,‚Äù which he says is a more masculine way to describe it.

In the fall of 2003, on the heels of Aire and his intellectual property holding company Solid 21 Inc. filing to register the ‚ÄúRed Gold‚Äù name as a trademark for use on watches and jewelry with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, they were issued a registration.

While Aire has built up a client list that has included Jamie Foxx, Angelina Jolie, Eva Longoria, Halle Berry, Jay Z, and Clint Eastwood, the brand really started making headlines in 2010 when Solid 21 filed suit in a California federal court against Rolex, LVMH Mo√´t Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Richemont, and Omega, among more than a dozen other companies. According to the complaint, nearly 20 different watch brands were using the words ‚ÄúRed Gold‚Äù in connection with their products without its authorization.

That suit ‚Äì which was eventually split into a number of different cases ‚Äì kicked off a lengthy and ever-growing chain of multi-million dollar trademark infringement cases that have dotted court dockets across the U.S., in which Solid 21 asserts that it has the exclusive right to use the ‚ÄúRed Gold‚Äù trademark. Solid 21 filed dozens of lawsuits between November 2010 and December 2013, alone, against the likes of Bulgari, Ulysee Nardin, Chopard, Pierre Kunz, and Franck Muller, among others. Even more would follow.

Of the many cases filed, one landed Hublot owner LVMH on the receiving end. With a fierce team of both in-house and outside counsel, LVMH sought to establish that the ‚ÄúRed Gold‚Äù term is generic when it is used in connection with jewelry and/or watches, and thus, it is not protectable as a trademark regardless of whether Solid 21 can show that consumers have come to associate the term with it and its products.

To bolster the argument that ‚ÄúRed Gold‚Äù is merely a generic term to describe rose gold, counsel for LVMH pointed to a dozen different patents that use the term ‚Äúred gold‚Äù to describe the material of jewelry or watches, and more than 60 different articles that use the term ‚Äúred gold‚Äù in a generic manner.

‚ÄúTo grant trademark status to a generic term essentially gives a single user a monopoly and prevents all other manufacturers from accurately identifying their products,‚Äù LVMH argued in a 2014 bid for interlocutory review. Ultimately, LVMH and Solid 21 resolved the matter and entered into a confidential settlement agreement in 2018, following more than 8 years of proceedings before federal courts in California.

The Solid 21, LVMH settlement came roughly 5 years after Aire and co. settled the virtually identical suit they filed against Breitling. While it appeared as though Solid 21 and Breitling had resolved their differences by way of a October 2013 settlement agreement, Solid 21 reignited the fight and filed a new suit against the Swiss luxury watchmaker last week in a federal court in Connecticut.

In something of a d√©j√† vu filing, Solid 21 claims that Breitling‚Äôs use of the words ‚ÄúRed Gold‚Äù in its advertising constitutes trademark infringement and dilution, as well as false designation of origin. It turns out, the case that the two parties had settled was dismissed without prejudice, meaning that Solid 21 could bring the same claims against the same defendant again in the future. And that is precisely what it has done.

This repeat lawsuit tactic is hardly a novel one for Solid 21. Less than one year after entering into an out-of-court settlement with Cartier, Jaeger-LeCoultre, Officine Panerai, and Piaget‚Äôs parent company Richemont in 2011, Solid 21 filed suit against the Swiss conglomerate again for allegedly infringing its ‚ÄúRed Gold‚Äù trademark.

In that case, just as in the many others that preceded and have succeeded it, Solid 21 claims that Richemont‚Äôs ‚Äúuse of the ‚ÄòRed Gold‚Äô mark in the design, manufacturing, marketing, advertising, and/or sale of their products is likely to cause confusion‚Äù amongst consumers as to whether ‚ÄúSolid 21 is somehow affiliated, connected, or associated with Richemont‚Äù and its products. As a result, Solid 21 argues that it ‚Äúhas suffered and will continue to suffer irreparable injury to its business, reputation, and goodwill, and will sustain loss of revenue and profits, while [Richemont] profits from such prohibited use.‚Äù

All the while, Solid 21 has routinely asserted ‚Äì including by way of many strongly-worded press releases circulated by its public relations arm ‚Äì that the ‚ÄúRed Gold‚Äù trademark is synonymous with Chris Aire and its upscale offerings. Yet, as the brand‚Äôs name continues to appear on complaints in courts across the country, Chris Aire and Solid 21 are arguably becoming far better known for their litigiousness than any type of jewelry offerings.

Titre: Are Gucci, LVMH's donations to rebuild Notre-Dame part of a brand-building exercise? - The Economic Times
Contenu:
Agencies In this file photo dated Monday, April 15, 2019, with the Eiffel Tower behind, left, flames and smoke rise from the blaze at Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris that destroyed its spire and its roof but spared its twin medieval bell towers, and prompted a frantic rescue effort to save its most precious artefacts.

If the fire at Notre Dame cathedral had happened 20 or 50 years ago, France‚Äôs luxury fashion houses would surely have rushed to support its reconstruction as quickly as they did in 2019.There is no doubting the sincerity of LVMH Kering SA and their founding families, who led the way with donations after the devastation earlier this week. The city of Paris, its streets and landmarks, have held a special role as the artistic center of the industry since its earliest days, so to restore what has been lost is to preserve its own history.But more than a century after Coco Chanel sold her first hat, the titans of luxury have even more reason to ensure Notre Dame recovers.And it is not just that they are among the wealthiest in France ‚Äî LVMH‚Äôs Bernard Arnault is France‚Äôs richest man and Francois Pinault , who created Kering SA, ranks third. L‚ÄôOreal SA and its principal shareholder, the Bettencourt Meyers family, are also key donors.Fashion generates 2.7 percent of French gross domestic product. Luxury, including L‚ÄôOreal, represents 19.8 percent of the CAC 40 index. With such a sizable share of the nation‚Äôs business, it‚Äôs only natural that the leading producers of high-end goods would step up to preserve one of their country‚Äôs iconic locations.It‚Äôs important that they do, because selling high-end goods has changed over the past decade. The lines are blurring between fashion, art, travel and culture, and developing a brand depends on so much more than offering the latest It bag. Success means blending all these elements together, so there‚Äôs a drive to branch out.The big groups are already involved in art and restoration. LVMH opened the Fondation Louis Vuitton, a Frank Gehry-designed center for contemporary arts, on the western edge of Paris in 2016. Pinault, meanwhile, is building a museum to house his private art collection at the former Bourse de Commerce, in the center of Paris.Notre Dame is associated with heritage and beauty, values that resonate within the luxury industry. Preserving the cathedral burnishes donors‚Äô position as a guardian of those characteristics, which in turn highlights the broader lifestyle they seek to promote.Landmark preservation fits well with this ethos.Fendi, part of the LVMH empire, contributed $2 million to the repair of the Trevi fountain in Rome. Sister brand Bulgari donated $1.7 million to overhaul the city‚Äôs Spanish Steps. Outside of the Arnault stable, Italian leather goods group Tod‚Äôs SpA has underwritten the $28 million restoration of the Colosseum in Rome.Their altruism works best on high-profile sites that appeal to tourists, as their donations also literally put their names on the map for the millions of visitors to key locations each year. Fendi even held a fashion show at the Trevi Fountain under the late Karl Lagerfeld. A restored Notre Dame will be no different (though fashion shows may not be allowed).The real prize for the French houses is to assure their connection to the Chinese, who are the number one buyers of luxury goods globally. LVMH and Kering each generate about a third of their sales from Asia excluding Japan.Paris is one of the main destinations for travelers from this region, and anything that affects visits can also impact sales of luxury goods. For example, the 2015 tourist attacks on the city, and the recent yellow vest protests, hurt demand. On the other hand, a weaker euro can lift sales. For these companies, there is a special urgency to ensure that Paris is preserved.When Notre Dame is finally rebuilt, donors will rightly be credited with rescuing a symbol of the city.They‚Äôll also have created an even bigger draw for visitors. It makes good business sense for them to have taken part.

Titre: How a Mall Is Bringing Everyone, Including Bernard Arnault, to Chengdu - Jing Daily
Contenu:
There must be something spectacular about Chengdu IFS if French billionaire and LVMH CEO Bernard Arnault decided to visit the luxury shopping mall earlier this month to learn why his brands are performing so well there.

Chengdu IFS opened in 2014 and is now the top luxury shopping destination in the city, as well as one of the most influential premium malls in China‚Äôs Midwest region. The 210,000-sqm, nine-floor shopping mall, which was developed by the Hong Kong property company The Wharf Holdings, is today the home to over 600 luxury, fashion, and lifestyle shops and services. 15 percent of those stores are "ultra-luxury" brands, 34 percent are premium fashion brands, 18 percent are affordable luxury brands, and the rest are dining, entertainment, and lifestyle services.

A number of high-profile luxury brands from Chanel and Moynat to Moncler and Tom Ford opened their first-ever flagship stores in the region at Chengdu IFS, while brands like Dior and Arnault's Louis Vuitton have their largest regional stores there. All of this indicates just how strategic Chengdu IFS is to luxury brands like LVMH wanting to shore up their retail networks in Chengdu, one of China's biggest tier-two cities that holds an enormous potential of luxury consumption.

Christina Hau, Wharf China Estates Limited Assistant Director and General Manager (Retail Leasing amp; Operations). Courtesy photo

‚ÄúSince the opening, the mall has achieved double-digit growth in both sales and rentals each year,‚Äù said Christina Hau, Wharf China Estates Limited Assistant Director and General Manager (Retail Leasing & Operations), about the mall's success. ‚ÄúMany luxury brands are satisfied with their performance at Chengdu IFS, with a lot of them seeing their sales here entering the brand‚Äôs top three rankings in China.‚Äù This robust growth has continued even as China‚Äôs economic growth has experienced a downturn ‚Äî something that usually dampens consumer confidence and affects retail performance. ‚ÄúOur business is still performing strongly based on the sales figures in the first quarter of this year, and the growth of many international top-tier luxury brands has not seen signs of a slowdown due to China‚Äôs macroeconomic environment,‚Äù said Hau.

The cozy and laid-back culture in Chengdu, where the locals also insist on living life to the fullest, makes it a unique place for luxury consumption. ‚ÄúPeople in Chengdu and the neighboring regions know how to enjoy life through shopping and eating‚Ä¶ They are also less sensitive to prices compared to consumers in other Chinese cities," Hau explained. "To them, shopping has to bring happiness and fulfillment. They are rarely fussy about prices.‚Äù That's why as the third-largest fashion capital in China (behind Beijing and Shanghai), Chengdu has yet to experience any economic impact on the city‚Äôs luxury purchasing power.

Chengdu IFS is located in one of the city's most vibrant economic areas, the commercial Chunxi Road region, right alongside other major shopping malls and department stores like Taikoo Li and Parkson. It's easy for consumers to travel there from all corners of Chengdu via public transportation or cabs for their shopping needs.

Its convenient location also makes Chengdu IFS a must-see for tourists. ‚ÄúThe mall is a landmark of the city,‚Äù said Hau. ‚ÄúAccording to our client-profiling data, a great number of our customers are actually coming from outside of Chengdu and are here to travel or on business trips. For instance, they come from Guizhou, Tibet, Zhejiang, Beijing, and Shanghai. Many of them are even our gold card holders.‚Äù

But Chengdu IFS is even bigger than you think. It's not a standalone shopping mall, but instead is part of a large-scale commercial complex that includes three ‚ÄúGrade A‚Äù office buildings, one luxury hotel, and one high-end service apartment building. To an extent, Chengdu IFS‚Äôs commercial concept is similar to New York City‚Äôs new landmark Hudson Yards development, which offers everything from shopping and working to dining and entertainment in the hopes that they'll keep customers inside their economic zone for as long as possible.

The width of brand selection at Chengdu IFS meets the diverse needs of the city's luxury shoppers. Consumers who prefer a conventional luxury shopping experience can visit the floors 1-3, where boutique stores from well-known luxury brands are showcasing their newest collections. ‚ÄúOur mall has a deep diversity of luxury goods. Some items that you won‚Äôt be able to find in Hong Kong can be found here,‚Äù said Winnie Wong, Chengdu IFS Brand & Marketing Deputy General Manager.

But Chengdu IFS also didn't miss out on edgy or niche luxury fashion brands that have yet to gain a foothold in China but are already trending with the country‚Äôs forward-looking fashionistas. The first Lane Crawford store in China‚Äôs Midwest region is located in this part of Chengdu IFS (floors 3-4), which offers a slew of hot, young designer labels such as The Row, Thom Browne, Gabriela Hearst, and Sacai.

Chengdu IFS is located in one of the city's most vibrant economic areas, the commercial Chunxi Road region, right alongside other major shopping malls and department stores like Taikoo Li and Parkson. Courtesy photo

The quality of visitors to a mall is crucial in deciding its business performance. In this respect, Chinese supermodel Lv Yan, who is also the founder of contemporary womenswear brand Comme Moi , endorsed Chengdu IFS‚Äôs efforts to attract wealthy customers for their brands.

‚ÄúChengdu IFS has gathered a group of high-quality customers through hosting a lot of business, culture and art events, which is highly helpful,‚Äù said Lv. Her store debuted at the mall's Lane Crawford store in early 2015. After seeing steady sales growth, Comme Moi launched a pop-up store from August 14-27, 2017, where it scored around 119,200 (RMB 800,000) in sales. Today, the brand is operating as an independent boutique store at Chengdu IFS.

Aside from gaining new customers, the mall recognizes the importance of retaining their existing ones. Chengdu IFS has designed its own VIP program that hosts over 260,000 members thus far. It also extends their shopping experience to digital platforms like WeChat, where members can participate in online events, redeem points, and purchase products on its mini-program store. A highlight of its offerings to high-end VIP clients is a concierge delivery service that ships luxury goods home for them ‚Äî an initiative that's been highly praised by the mall's luxury brands.

Chengdu IFS‚Äôs gigantic and iconic panda sculpture, which hangs over its main entrance, is a commission created by artist Lawrence Argent. Courtesy photo

Like many successful shopping malls around the globe, Chengdu IFS is witnessing contemporary art become a steady influence on millennials and Generation Z, and it's actively following this trend as a way to embrace these art-lennials. Since its inception, art has been a vital part of the mall's DNA, with unique art installations punctuating the giant space to make it feel more like a tourist attraction. For example, Chengdu IFS‚Äôs gigantic and iconic panda sculpture, which hangs over its main entrance, is a commission created by artist Lawrence Argent. The sculpture has become the most Instagram-able place of the mall today, attracting hundreds and thousands of visitors to come and take pictures each day.

Occasionally, Chengdu IFS is used as the venue to host large-scale city events, such as the Parcours Art Festival in September, which was a joint initiative between the Chengdu government and the high-end Parisian neighborhood of Saint-Germain-des-Pr√©s. With the mall's help, luxury brands Fendi, Chopard, and Loewe co-presented themed art exhibitions during the festival to reach Chinese customers via creative storytelling. Moynat, Longchamp, and Comme Moi even released exclusive products to celebrate it. And this April, Chengdu IFS is once again going celebrate Tibetan culture and art as a way to bridge the gap of understanding between Tibet and the rest of China.

So, is Chengdu IFS‚Äôs success replicable? Not all cities have access to Chengdu's desirable luxury customers (who care more about the shopping experience than price tags) but the way Chengdu IFS operates may offer some good lessons to struggling mall retailers. It has all the key ingredients: good location, high-quality client base, a solid retail network of strong brands, and most importantly, top-notch environment and services. With all of this at its disposal, it would be hard not to thrive.

Titre: LVMH-backed label to widen portfolio | The Standard - Hong Kong Standard
Contenu:
Mainland fashion menswear brand GXG, backed by luxury goods giant LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE, refiled its Hong Kong initial public offering application under the new name of Mulsanne recently.

The Ningbo-based brand filed the initial application in March last year, aiming to raise up to US$300 million (HK$2.34 billion), according to Bloomberg.

Founded in 2007, Mulsanne's brand portfolio consists of GXG series, including GXG, gxg jeans and gxg.kids, as well as sportswear brands Yatlas and 2XU, targeting mid- to high-end customers. The company generated over 96 percent of revenue from the GXG series and over 66 percent from the GXG brand in the past 3 years.

L Catterton Asia and Crescent Point, two private equity firms backed by LVMH, bought a majority stake in GXG in 2016.

Mulsanne accounted for about 3.3 percent of the menswear market share and ranked second in mainland China in 2018 in terms of total retail revenue, according to industry consultant China Insights Consultancy.

Mulsanne operated 2,251 retail stores in China including 723 self-owned stores, 536 partnership stores and 992 distributor stores, as of March this year.

Its online distribution channels include major online platforms, such as Alibaba's Tmall and Taobao, as well as Tencent's (0700) WeChat mini program. Revenue generated from sales of apparel through online channels increased from 23.7 percent in 2016 to 34.5 percent in 2017, and further to 35.7 percent in 2018.

Mulsanne recorded 11.2 percent year-on-year decline in net profit for 2018 to 374.5 million yuan (HK$436.28 million). Gross profit margin also fell by 0.4 percentage points to 53.7 percent in 2018, mainly due to the increasing cost of purchases, while the product prices remained stable, as well as the change in revenue mix, the firm says.

The cost of apparel products grew by 9.08 percent year-on-year to 1.74 billion yuan in 2018.

Meanwhile, actual sales return rate continued to rise, up by 2.6 percentage points to 26.8 percent in 2017, and further to 35 percent in 2018.

The increase in actual sales return rate from 2017 to 2018 was primarily because its VIP distributors, who were allowed to return products during the period from 2017 to the first quarter of 2018, mostly returned the products in 2018, the company says.

Mulsanne typically achieves higher revenue from the sales of autumn and winter collections due to the higher average unit selling price. Also, it records higher sales typically before holiday seasons such as Chinese New Year and during major promotion periods such as Alibaba's Singles' Day, it says.

The sales and inventory could fluctuate due to extreme or unusual weather. Fast Retailing (9983), the owner of Uniqlo and GU, and Bossini (0592) posted a net profit drop and extended its loss respectively at the beginning this year as the unseasonably warm weather hit winter sales.

In September 2017, Mulsanne obtained a syndicated banking facility of up to US$226 million from 12 banks including Citibank Hong Kong and CMB International Finance through share pledging. The facility is scheduled to mature in September 2022.

All of the amounts had been drawn down under the facility, and US$22.6 million of the borrowing has been repaid as of March this year, the company says.

Mulsanne intends to use part of net proceeds of its flotation to repay debt and reduce financial expenses.

Another portion of the net proceeds will be deployed to expand the brand and product portfolio by pursuing brand acquisitions or strategic alliances, upgrade offline retail stores to smart stores, establish an advanced smart logistics center, and for working capital and other general corporate purposes.

Titre: Who is Bernard Arnault and why is Europe's richest man so keen to save Notre Dame - The Mirror
Contenu:
He's France's richest man, was a witness at French President Nicolas Sarkozy's wedding, and is now pledge to saving Notre Dame - this is what you need to know about Bernard Arnault

Who is Bernard Arnault and why is Europe's richest man so keen to save Notre Dame

His luxury goods empire includes Louis Vuitton and Christian Dior, but now Bernard Arnault is stepping up to save Notre Dame.

And he's certainly not short of a bob or two. The 70-year-old is the richest man in Europe - with a luxury goods empire the envy of the world.

A lover of the arts, the iconic structure is in need of Mr Arnault's help. Huge parts of the 850-year-old building in Paris have been destroyed in the blaze last night, including the iconic spire and roof.

"In the wake of this national tragedy, the Arnault family and the LVMH Group pledge their support for #NotreDame. They will donate a total of 200 million euros to the fund for reconstruction of this architectural work, which is an integral part of the history of France," the official account of the LVMH Group Tweeted on Tuesday morning in the wake of the devastating fire that has destroyed so much of the 800-year-old cathedral.

But who is Bernard Arnault and how did his family build up its ¬£70 billion fortune?

Starting out

Arnault was born in Roubaix, France ‚Äì a couple of hours drive from Paris on the Belgian border ‚Äì in 1949. He studied engineering, his dad owned a civil engineering firm, in the suburbs of Paris and graduated in 1971.

After university he joined his dad's firm ‚Äì changing its focus to real estate and specialising in holiday accommodation. By 1979 he'd taken over as president.

Five years later he changed focus again, taking over Financi√®re Agache, then selling everything the company owned except the Christian Dior brand and Le Bon March√© department store.

His move into luxury goods would be one that turned him from well off into one of the richest people alive.

Louis Vuitton Mo√´t Hennesy

Image: Amber Gordon/Instagram) Amber Gordon/Instagram)

Arnault first got involved with Louis Vuitton Mo√´t Hennesy (LVMH) in 1987 ‚Äì shortly after the two firms merged.

The luxury group held rights to some of Dior's perfumes, and he mediated a dispute between the chief executive of Mo√´t and Louis Vuitton's president.

In 1988 he teamed up with Guinness and put money into a firm that held 24% of LVMH's shares, in January 1989 he spent even more cash to take control of 43.5% of its shares and made himself important enough to block any plans to dismantle the group.

After this he was unanimously elected chairman of the firm.

Under his guidance LVMH saw its sales and profits soar 500% as it rose to be one of the biggest luxury brands on the planet while Arnault's personal wealth saw him listed as the richest man in France and the 4th richest man in 2019.

Interest in the arts

Image: Reuters) Reuters)

Arnault's move to provide funds and help to Notre Dame is entirely fitting with his interest in art and history, and long association with Paris.

His personal collection includes works by Picasso and French artist Yves Klein, as well as Any Warhol and Henry Moore.

He also started the Louis Vuitton Foundation ‚Äì an art museum and cultural centre - building project and was instrumental in turning LVMH into a major supporter of art in France.

He's currently married to Canadian pianist H√©l√®ne Mercier ‚Äì his second wife ‚Äì and has one daughter and four sons.

This will ensure traceability and guarantee the authenticity of the products, which are common targets for counterfeiting.

The report, Making Blockchain Real: LVMH and the Future of Authentic Luxury, found that appetite for technologies that could ensure the authenticity of luxury goods was extremely high, with the majority of consumers expressing concern about possible counterfeiting.

In a survey of 1,500 consumers conducted by Certilogo across the UK, the US, Italy, France and China, 83% said that they had been concerned that brand-name products they had purchased might be counterfeit.

This was even higher in China, one of the biggest consumers of luxury goods, where 95% of respondents expressed concern over the issue.

Louis Vuitton blockchain plans mark the start of an industry wide transformation

According to Certilogo, the Louis Vuitton blockchain project is likely to be the start of an industry wide change, as other brands seek to follow suit. Reports have also suggested LVMH is likely to offer the technology as a white-label solution to other luxury brands, making rapid proliferation plausible.

Titre: Notre-Dame cathedral fire: 5 facts to know about the Paris church - Options The Edge
Contenu:
[Updated: April 17, 2019]

Apple has joined two French millionaires in a pledge to rebuild Notre-Dame after the devastating fire. The size of the donation is unclear but CEO Tim Cook has released a statement via twitter:



We are heartbroken for the French people and those around the world for whom Notre Dame is a symbol of hope. Relieved that everyone is safe. Apple will be donating to the rebuilding efforts to help restore Notre Dame‚Äôs precious heritage for future generations. ‚Äî Tim Cook (@tim_cook) April 16, 2019



Fran√ß‚Äã‚Äãois-Henri Pinault, CEO of French luxury group Kering, which owns brands like Gucci, Yves Saint Laurent and Balenciaga, mentioned on Monday night that he and his family will be donating ‚Ç¨100 million (RM467 million) to rebuild the cathedral.

Bernard Arnault, the chair of LVMH, doubled that donation on Tuesday morning. LVMH, the world‚Äôs largest luxury-goods company, includes brands Louis Vuitton and Christian Dior.



---

A raging fire yesterday evening tore through the revered Gothic cathedral, destroying its delicate spire in front of horrified onlookers and sending its art repository up in flames. The 850-year-old relic, whose name means Our Lady, is the seat of the archbishop of Paris, and home to various artefacts and artworks collected over the centuries.

Visited by over 14 million visitors a year, the symbol of beauty has witnessed much of French history, including the coronation of Henry VI as King of France and Napoleon as emperor. President Emmanuel Macron described the fire as a ‚Äúterrible tragedy‚Äù on national TV, with the fire-engulfed still behind him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm telling you all tonight ‚Äì we will rebuild this cathedral together. This is probably part of the French destiny. And we will do it in the next years. Starting tomorrow, a national donation scheme will be started that will extend beyond our borders.‚Äù

WATCH: Notre Dame's spire collapses into the flames, video from witness Nicolas Marang shows. https://t.co/MaEI5HttSM pic.twitter.com/gHhwMrRYmS ‚Äî NBC News (@NBCNews) April 15, 2019

Emergency services said that most invaluable artefacts are salvaged, including The Crown of Thorns, said to have been worn by Jesus Christ before the crucifixion, and the tunic of St Louis. While the cause of the fire is still under investigation, Parisians and tourists have gathered outside the church, raising their voices in prayer.

Macron lamented the destruction of the awe-inspiring building, calling it a place where the French live their greatest moments, ‚Äúfrom wars to pandemics to liberations‚Äù. Here are five more facts about this feat of architecture that sealed its status as a cultural symbol of France.



Paris‚Äô point zero

A geographic marker, embedded in the concrete of the public square just outside of Notre-Dame Cathedral, is the central point from which all roads in France are measured. One of a number of ‚Äúkilometre zeroes‚Äù around the world, the centre of Paris is marked by an octagonal brass plate, sparking a surprising number of local rituals, from spinning in a circle on one foot atop to gain your heart‚Äôs desire or kissing a loved one to ensure eternal devotion.

A forest top

There‚Äôs a reason the roof of Notre-Dame is called ‚Äúthe Forest‚Äù. Containing one of the oldest surviving wood-timbre frames in Paris, the cathedral is supported by wooden beams, each constructed from an individual tree. At least 52 acres of trees were cut down in the 12th century to support the medieval roof structure. (Ed: Reports have claimed that the wooden latticework inside the cathedral had fuelled the fire that consumed the iconic church).

View of Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris from the banks of the river Seine in Paris (Photo: Charles Platiau/Reuters)

The bells were once melted down for artillery

Interestingly, the bells of Notre-Dame bear names such as Emmanuel, Gabriel, Marcel, Etienne, Maurice, Jean-Marie, etc. However, the bells we now hear are not the same ones installed upon completion of the cathedral 600 years ago. Like other churches around France, it was transformed in the late 18th century from a Christian space to the new Cult of Reason. All 20 of its bells, except the enormous Emmanuel, were melted down to make cannons. The public remarked that the instruments were not as intricately made as the older versions as they make a dissonant chime but a new ensemble of bells were restored to its 17th-century sound in 2013.

A honeyed roof

The south side of the cathedral is home to a surprising group of residents ‚Äì bees. On the building‚Äôs sacristy, a bee hive was installed in the spring of 2013 as part of a Parisian trend. The Buckfast bees, a strain developed by a monk named Brother Adam ‚Äì are known for their gentleness. Their honey, made from the flowering plants from the city‚Äôs balconies and gardens, were given away to the poor.

Statues of biblical kings were beheaded

Twenty eight ‚Äì that‚Äôs the number of statues that were pulled down with ropes and decapitated by a mob. During the Revolution, the people was so disgusted with the monarchy that they took down every symbol of royalty on the streets of Paris. However, the statues that were removed were not of French Kings, but representations of the kings of Judah. It wasn‚Äôt until 1977 that the heads of 21 of these kings were discovered during work on the basement of the French Bank of Foreign Trade. They can now be observed in the Mus√©e du Moyen-√Çge de Cluny (Middle-Ages Museum of Cluny) on the left bank.

Titre: Bulgari, Armani, Versace: Why luxury fashion brands open hotels as more get into the game - TODAY
Contenu:
HONG KONG ‚Äî Late last year LVMH made headlines when it announced it was acquiring travel and luxury hospitality group Belmond. While it was not the luxury conglomerate‚Äôs first foray into hospitality ‚Äì it owns and operates its own brand of hotels called Cheval Blanc ‚Äì it signalled a larger trend that has seen more fashion and lifestyle brands enter the hospitality sector.

‚ÄúFashion and hospitality are both aspirational, experiential and a reflection of one‚Äôs lifestyle, so there are plenty of synergies there,‚Äù says Ms Catherine Feliciano-Chon, managing partner of marketing agency CatchOn.

‚ÄúBeing able to have a physical space beyond a conventional retail store is immensely powerful in bringing that brand to life and opens them up to a lot of other product categories, like furniture.‚Äù

The fashion-branded hotel emerged in the early noughties when Versace opened its first Palazzo in Australia. Brands including Armani and Ferragamo followed (the latter built its own portfolio of hotels under the Lungarno Collection), while fashion designers started collaborating with hotel groups on interiors and other projects.

Today the market is dominated by several players including Bulgari, which currently boasts six hotels with three more planned to open in Moscow, Tokyo and Paris by the end of 2022.

‚ÄúThe hotel industry is a very different business from fashion, so not all the brands that started this venture were successful,‚Äù says Mr Silvio Ursini, vice-president of Bulgari Hotels and Resorts. ‚ÄúAt the moment only a very few ‚Äòfashion‚Äô brands are still present in the hospitality scene.

Consistency with brand values and identity is the key for success in any diversification process, but in the hospitality sector it is particularly challenging and the reason why it is still a growing trend.‚Äù

Unlike their predecessors, the new generation of branded hotels are built around the idea of creating experiences and communities.

The luxury watchmaker Audemars Piguet, for example ‚Äì which recently announced it would be opening its first hotel ‚Äì did not choose a thriving capital like London or Zurich for its property, but the small village of Le Brassus in Switzerland‚Äôs Vall√©e de Joux, where its headquarters and manufacturing facilities are based.

Guests will be able to ski down the hotel‚Äôs zigzagging roof or visit the nearby Mus√©e Atelier Audemars Piguet, which will feature over 1,300 timepieces.

‚ÄúThe real value of these type of operations, as well as the return on investment, lies in the possibility to tap into alternative marketing tools and create an experiential channel,‚Äù says Ms Cristiana Schiavolin, a management consultant working with direct-to-consumer brands and retail operators.

‚ÄúMuch of retail has lost its human touch, but hospitality still delivers analogue experiences people are longing for, such as access to a community sharing similar tastes and values.‚Äù

A similar proposition has influenced plans for the latest Cheval Blanc property in London. As well as opening the hotel in the city‚Äôs Mayfair district, the group will redevelop parts of the neighbourhood.

The hotel will be linked to restaurants, an underground spa, high-end retail outlets and the first-ever Louis Vuitton cafe, creating a hub rather than just a stand-alone hotel.

These new fashion hotels will continue to evolve as younger customers come to the fore. More mobile and worldly than the generation before, these travellers are more likely to pay for branded experiences versus a luxury product, making hotels the ideal place to spend their money while learning about the brand through a different channel.

Promoting a particular ‚Äúculture‚Äù will also become increasingly important, as evidenced by cheaper brands like Shinola and Muji launching their own hotels.

‚ÄúWe live in a world of ‚Äòtribes‚Äô that have different preferences, inclinations to shopping and purchasing powers,‚Äù Ms Schiavolin says. ‚ÄúMost importantly, they each value their cultures. Adamantly, Shinola and Muji hotels talk to a customer who appreciates design and does not necessarily need a luxury environment. It‚Äôs about a service philosophy.‚Äù

But the long-term success of any hotel comes down to more than just branding. Operations require specific knowledge and expertise, which is why potential partnerships with other hotel groups could only drive this trend further.

‚ÄúSimply put, fashion brands don‚Äôt know how to run hotels,‚Äù Ms Feliciano-Chon says. ‚ÄúSo while they may lend their name or create a branded concept, they still rely on a hotel group to run it. Bulgari is a good example as it‚Äôs part of the Marriott group.

‚ÄúWith the case of LVMH, having Belmond as part of their portfolio strengthens the resources of Cheval Blanc. I‚Äôm betting that Belmond will be providing the operational and human resources to help Cheval Blanc grow.‚Äù SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST
